title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: interest fostering open welcoming environment, contributors maintainers pledge make participation project community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity expression, level experience, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes creating positive environment include: Using welcoming inclusive language respectful differing viewpoints experiences Gracefully accepting constructive criticism Focusing best community Showing empathy towards community members Examples unacceptable behavior participants include: use sexualized language imagery unwelcome sexual attention advances Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical electronic address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Project maintainers responsible clarifying standards acceptable behavior expected take appropriate fair corrective action response instances unacceptable behavior. Project maintainers right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, ban temporarily permanently contributor behaviors deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within project spaces public spaces individual representing project community. Examples representing project community include using official project e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event. Representation project may defined clarified project maintainers.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported contacting project team. complaints reviewed investigated result response deemed necessary appropriate circumstances. project team obligated maintain confidentiality regard reporter incident. details specific enforcement policies may posted separately. Project maintainers follow enforce Code Conduct good faith may face temporary permanent repercussions determined members project’s leadership.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 1.4, available http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Thank interest contributing vsreport! welcome contributions everyone. guidelines help get started.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: encounter bugs suggestions improvements, please create issue GitHub. reporting issue, please provide much detail possible, including: clear descriptive title. detailed description issue. rough topic issue relates . Steps reproduce issue bug, alongside relevant error messages. Acceptance Criteria consider satisfactory solution.

what: Make sure the repository is set up

text: Create new branch development branch. Make sure name relevant issue trying solve.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Make changes codebase, line existing style. Write update tests appropriate. Ensure code works test data desired. Document new functionality changes appropriate documentation.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Make sure changes introduced knock-effects rest codebase running full test suite:
code: devtools::test()

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Commit changes descriptive message: making commits branch, follow DSC Coding Standards guidelines version control. means every commit aspire message following structure: <type> element one following tags: feat: new feature fix: bug fix doc: Documentation changes style: Changes affect meaning code. example, white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc. refactor: code change neither fixes bug adds feature perf: code change improves performance test: Adding missing tests chore: Changes build process auxiliary tools libraries. example, documentation generation. <subject> element finish sentence: accepted commit . <body> element short description provides info files changed bit detail changes made. Finally, <footer> can contain auxiliary info, ticket commit working towards fixing.
code: git add . fit commit -m "Feat: Description of the changes" <type>: <subject> <BLANK LINE> <body> <BLANK LINE> <footer>

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Push changes relevant branch:
code: git push origin my-feature-branch

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: Go repository GitHub navigate “Pull Requests” tab. Click “New Pull Request” button. Select feature branch, made changes. Select development branch destination. Provide clear descriptive title pull request. Provide detailed description changes (link existing issue). Submit pull request.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: new pull request created, subject peer review. review process follow guidelines set duck book. Reviewers follow series steps: Read understand ticket acceptance criteria. quick look GitHub pull request see changed. Update data code locally ensure testing right environment. Make sure branch. Run test suite ensure code conforms style guide. Run pipeline ensure functionality claims achieved. Throughout process reviewers write comments, using GitHub functionality usually good starting place. changes requested communication peers strongly encouraged. order standardise review process reviewers follow template bellow. ensure consistent feedback: merge approved, ticked closed relevant branch deleted. tech-debt associated ticket must spun-new tickets merge happens.
code: ##  Code review  #### Documentation  Any new code includes all the following forms of documentation:  - [ ] **Function Documentation** as docstrings within the function definition. - [ ] **Examples** demonstrating major functionality, which runs successfully locally.  #### Functionality  - [ ] **Installation**: Installation or build of the code succeeds. - [ ] **Functionality**: Any functional claims of new code have been confirmed. - [ ] **Automated tests**: Unit tests cover essential functions for a reasonable range   of inputs and conditions. All tests pass on your local machine. - [ ] **Packaging guidelines**: New code conforms to the project contribution   guidelines. ---  ### Review comments  *Insert detailed comments here!*  These might include, but not exclusively:  - bugs that need fixing (does it work as expected? and does it work with other code that it is likely to interact with?) - alternative methods (could it be written more efficiently or with more clarity?) - documentation improvements (does the documentation reflect how the code actually works?) - additional tests that should be implemented (do the tests effectively assure that it  works correctly?) - code style improvements (could the code be written more clearly?)  Your suggestions should be tailored to the code that you are reviewing. Be critical and clear, but not mean. Ask questions and set actions.

title: Contributing to vsreport
text: need help questions, feel free reach opening issue contacting maintainers directly. Thank contributing!

title: Description
text: code follows style contribution guidelines project. performed self-review code. commented code, particularly hard--understand areas. made corresponding changes documentation. changes generate new warnings. added tests prove fix effective feature works. New existing unit tests pass locally changes. dependent changes merged published downstream modules.

title: Package for CRVS Report
text: order use vsreport data, need follow straight forward commands. First, install package GitHub repo:

what: Install and Load the devtools Package
title: Package for CRVS Report
text: Install load devtools package haven’t already.
code: install.packages("devtools") library(devtools)

what: Install the vsreport Package from GitHub
title: Package for CRVS Report
text: Use install_github() function devtools package install package. need provide repository address format username/repository.
code: devtools::install_github("tech-acs/vsreport")

what: Use the vsreport in your Script
title: Package for CRVS Report
text: installed package, basic example use vsreport:
code: library(crvspackage)  # Example Usage age_grp_80 <- construct_age_groups(ageinyrs,                                         start_age = 5, max_band = 80,                                         step_size = 5, under_1 = TRUE)

title: Package for CRVS Report
text: want develop package, may want consider cloning repository following steps correct environment improve package. First, install vsreport GitHub, ensure package dependencies correctly managed installed using renv: 1.__Clone repository__: 2.__Initialize renv environment__: Upon first entering package directory, renv activate specific package environment defined vsreport. need run following R commands restore required packages: read renv.lock file contains dependencies install correct versions required packages. 3.__Install package__: environment set , can install package using: following steps, ensure necessary dependencies correct versions installed, allowing vsreport function intended. also mean can now open project develop package .
code: git clone https://github.com/tech-acs/vsreport.git cd vsreport install.packages("renv") renv::restore() devtools::install()

title: Package for CRVS Report
text: made significant changes package, might worth considering changing package version. can done DESCRIPTION file, bumping Version variable. order rebuild update vsreport making changes functions follow steps: steps package installed latest changes functions. mean package right state updated online repo.
code: # Remove the installed version of the package remove.packages("vsreport")  # Clear your R environment rm(list = ls())  # Restart R session (do this manually or with RStudio shortcut Ctrl+Shift+F10)  # Initialize renv if not already done if (!"renv" %in% installed.packages()) {   install.packages("renv") } library(renv)  # Restore the environment renv::restore()  # Update the lockfile renv::snapshot()  # Recreate documentation and rebuild the package library(devtools) document()  # Generates the NAMESPACE file and documentation using roxygen2 build()     # Builds the package install()   # Installs the package

title: construct_age_groups — construct_age_groups
text: Derives agegroupings according parameters set.

code: construct_age_groups(   age_in_yrs_col,   start_age,   max_band,   step_size,   under_1 = TRUE )

title: construct_age_groups — construct_age_groups
text: age_in_yrs_col name age years variable used derive group. start_age lowest age first group, excluding < 1, set 5 first group 01-04. max_band final band age groupings e.g. 85+. step_size width age band years. under_1 set TRUE require 'one year old' group.

title: construct_age_groups — construct_age_groups
text: returns agegroup based set parameters

title: construct_age_groups — construct_age_groups
code: data <- data %>% mutate(AGEGROUP = construct_age_groups(AGEINYRS, start_age = 5, max_band = 95, step_size = 5, under_1 = TRUE)) #> Error in data %>% mutate(AGEGROUP = construct_age_groups(AGEINYRS, start_age = 5,     max_band = 95, step_size = 5, under_1 = TRUE)): could not find function "%>%" data <- data %>% mutate(AGEGROUP = construct_age_groups(AGEINYRS, start_age = 30, max_band = 95, step_size = 5, under_1 = FALSE)) #> Error in data %>% mutate(AGEGROUP = construct_age_groups(AGEINYRS, start_age = 30,     max_band = 95, step_size = 5, under_1 = FALSE)): could not find function "%>%"
